comment._content: He looks happy in his work!!  :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Doesn't he?! This photo always makes me think that you wouldn't be long waiting for him to put the kettle on for a cuppa between trains... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is a brilliant shot of a fine looking man and his work environment.  Look at the gear in the cabin?  If my memory serves me right each train carried a staff and the 'points'could only be operatied when the correct staff was inserted into those objects with the slots in them.  It was a very well designed safety device in its time!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Ah, is that what a staff is? You are a mine of useFUL information! Look at this photo in our collections: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000148503/Image?lookfor=http:... I didn't know what the roundy thingy was. But how would that fit into the slots?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Here's a link that explains it and with pics as well. Notice the signalman's loop for grabbing the 'token' or 'staff' as it alternatively called. It's use is a safety feature that helps prevent train collisions on single-way tracks. Stuart. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Token_(railway_signalling)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Ah, excellent Stu - now I'll be able to use that photo for 18 May in the Year in the Life of our collections, and will astound everyone with my railway erudition...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] I know them as 'tokens' and their use evolved quite early in railway history (from around 1850). This system is mentioned in the section about 'signaling' from The Victorian Railway and how it evolved by P J G Ransome (pp160-162). Published 1990 by William Heinemann Ltd of London, ISBN 0 434 98083 8. Hope that will be useful? Regards. Stuart. They are also called 'staffs' becaue when they were first used they looked like a short staff or touncheon.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is what I love about Flickr!  You get information and education from all over the place.  I come from a railway family and I remember riding in the Guards van at the back of the train (a great privilege) and watching him lean out and hook the staff from a stand or from a stationmasters hand as we passed through.  I never heard of "tokens" but I could see how that title would be applied to them.  Thank you Stuart!  That's an excellent shot of the staff on a loop in the collection NLI, you should put that up here as well.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Will do, but might save it for 18 May in our Year in the Life collection if I don't have a better one for that day...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie/] Thanks, but wish it was mine to upload here. It's just a link but an interesting one, I think. Stuart.
